raw_text:
Last Star Wars 'not for children'
 
 The sixth and final Star Wars movie may not be suitable for young children, film-maker George Lucas has said.
 
 He told US TV show 60 Minutes that Revenge of the Sith would be the darkest and most violent of the series. "I don't think I would take a five or six-year-old to this," he told the CBS programme, to be aired on Sunday. Lucas predicted the film would get a US rating advising parents some scenes may be unsuitable for under-13s. It opens in the UK and US on 19 May. He said he expected the film would be classified PG-13 - roughly equivalent to a British 12A rating.
 
 The five previous Star Wars films have all carried less restrictive PG - parental guidance - ratings in the US. In the UK, they have all been passed U - suitable for all - with the exception of Attack of The Clones, which got a PG rating in 2002. Revenge of the Sith - the third prequel to the original 1977 Star Wars film - chronicles the transformation of the heroic Anakin Skywalker into the evil Darth Vader as he travels to a Hell-like planet composed of erupting volcanoes and molten lava. "We're going to watch him make a pact with the devil," Lucas said. "The film is much more dark, more emotional. It's much more of a tragedy."

llama3.2:3b: George Lucas stated that Revenge of the Sith, the sixth Star Wars movie, may not be suitable for young children due to its dark and violent content, predicting a US PG-13 rating equivalent to a UK 12A classification, which differs from the less restrictive ratings given to previous films.

He notes this film will be the darkest of the series, depicting Anakin Skywalker's transformation into Darth Vader as he travels to a hellish planet filled with volcanic eruptions and lava.

qwen2.5:1.5b: George Lucas has stated that Star Wars: The Clone Wars may not be suitable for young children due to its darker themes and violence, as it would receive a PG-13 rating in the UK and US.
qwen2.5:3b: George Lucas, director of Star Wars, says his final installment may not be suitable for young children due to its darkness and violence. He predicts it will have a PG-13 rating in the US, equivalent to UK's 12A. Unlike previous films rated PG or U, this one is expected to be rated PG-13 in the US, reflecting more mature themes involving Anakin Skywalker transforming into Darth Vader.
opencoder:1.5b:
Last Star Wars movie not for children, George Lucas has predicted that the darkest and most violent of the series will be "Revenge of the Sith" aired on Sunday.
This opening scene of the film depicts the transformation of the epic Anakin Skywalker into the villainous Darth Vader. It is a dark and emotional tale set in the final frontier, where humanity and the living are transformed by the actions of two separate adversaries.

deepseek-r1:1.5b:
<think>
Okay, I need to summarize this text about Star Wars movies. Let me read through it carefully. The first sentence says that the last Star Wars 'not for children', which means it might not be suitable for kids. George Lucas told 60 Minutes that Revenge of the Sith would be dark and violent. He also mentioned parents should watch scenes around age 13, expecting a PG-13 rating. 

Next, he said previous films were less restrictive with ratings up to 12A in the UK. The fifth film was Attack of The Clones, which was rated PG, while others were higher. The main focus is on the third prequel, which is darker and more emotional than the original Star Wars movies.

So I should capture that it's a darker version, parents should watch carefully for kids, and include how Lucas predicted the rating. Also, mention the differing ratings in different countries.
</think>

Revenge of the Sith: The sixth Star Wars film may not be suitable for young children, according to George Lucas. He stated that the film would be dark and violent, advising parents to watch scenes aimed at children under 13 with a PG-13 rating. The previous five films had less restrictive ratings in the US, with Attack of The Clones being rated PG, while others were up to 12A in the UK. Revenge of the Sith, the third prequel, chronicles Skywalker's transformation into Darth Vader on a volcanic planet and is expected to be darker and more emotional than the original Star Wars films.
tinyllama:1.1b: Lucas warns that 'Star Wars: Episode VII - The Force Awakens' may be rated PG-13 or PG in the UK and US, but the sixth and final movie is not recommended for children. Lucas said that the film would be classified as an R in the US (parental guidance) and U (suitable for all), while in the UK it will most likely be rated PG (parental guidance) with a PG-13 rating possible. The movie takes place in a darker, more violent version of the Star Wars universe than the previous films have shown, and will feature some scenes that may not be suitable for children under 13 years old. The film is set to be released on May 19th in the UK and US, with an R rating recommended in the UK and an U rating possible in the US.
tinydolphin:1.1b: The sixth and final Star Wars movie, Revenge of the Sith, may not be suitable for children under the age of five, according to film-maker George Lucas. He told US TV show 60 Minutes that the film would be rated PG-13, a level of maturity that is somewhat lower than the PG rating given to previous Star Wars movies in the UK. However, he also anticipates the movie will be rated as PG-13 in the US, where it will open on May 19th. The five previous Star Wars films have all been classified either PG or PG-13 in the UK.
